verse.arabic_text: وَسَارِعُوا إِلَىٰ مَغْفِرَةٍ مِّن رَّبِّكُمْ وَجَنَّةٍ عَرْضُهَا السَّمَاوَاتُ وَالْأَرْضُ أُعِدَّتْ لِلْمُتَّقِينَ
verse.translation: And hasten to forgiveness from your Lord and a garden as wide as the heavens and earth, prepared for the righteous.

theme_question.correct: Hastening and competing in seeking Allah's forgiveness and Paradise
options: Delaying repentance until the end of one's life
Hastening and competing in seeking Allah's forgiveness and Paradise
Prioritizing worldly status over spiritual growth
Waiting for a miraculous sign before practicing faith

educational_notes.verse_context: This verse was revealed following the Battle of Uhud, a time of great physical and emotional trial for the early Muslim community. It served as a powerful reminder to pivot from worldly setbacks toward the eternal goal of Allah's pleasure.
educational_notes.theme_explanation: The word 'Saari'u' (hasten/race) implies that a believer should be proactive and energetic in their spiritual life. It suggests that forgiveness and Paradise are not things to be approached lazily, but are goals worth competing for.
educational_notes.surah_overview: Juz 4 completes Surah Al-Imran, which emphasizes steadfastness and the unity of the message of the Prophets, and begins Surah An-Nisa, which shifts the focus toward social justice, the protection of orphans, and the legal rights of women.
